current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To provide for the establishment of a Commission to
		  Accelerate the End of Breast Cancer.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Accelerating the End of Breast
			 Cancer Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text:
Sec. 1. Short title; table of
				contents.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
makes the following
			 findings:

text.#text:
In the United
			 States, the chance of a woman developing breast cancer during her lifetime has
			 increased from 1 in 11 in 1975 to 1 in 8 today.

Worldwide, breast
			 cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in women with 1,300,000 cases
			 each year. Breast cancer is also the leading cause of cancer death in women,
			 with more than 438,000 women dying from the disease worldwide in 2010, a 37.5
			 percent increase since 1990.

More than 90
			 percent of deaths from breast cancer are caused by metastasis, which occurs
			 when cancerous cells spread to other organs or bone.

The National
			 Cancer Institute estimated that breast cancer care in the United States cost
			 $16,500,000,000 in 2010, and cost the Nation $12,100,000,000 in lost
			 productivity.

Over the past 40
			 years, very little has improved the incidence, morbidity, and mortality rates
			 of breast cancer.

In recognition of
			 the complexity of breast cancer, experts have identified the need to transform
			 how research is conducted by engaging investigators from many
			 disciplines.

Advances in
			 understanding the progression of breast cancer, particularly metastasis, have
			 the potential to translate to better understanding and preventing the spread of
			 other types of cancer.

(in this Act
			 referred to as the

			 initiatives, partnerships, and research within the public and private sectors,
			 basic and applied sciences, and epidemiology that can be turned into strategies
			 to prevent breast cancer and breast cancer metastasis.
